I think that the cleaner and more long term way is to somehow extend the ImageCacheManager a little bit more to make it take care of downloading images.

That way, it can start a 'process of elimination' similar to the following:

- If `direct_location` exists and it's url scheme is `rbd`, try to download it directly.
- If we can't download it with that way, fallback to downloading from Glance API.

However, the thing I'd like to update to this would be to control where the cache is, so perhaps `image_cache_store=file` for the current behaviour that would reflects yours, but in our case, `image_cache_store=rbd` when we have different sites and want things cached there.

The behaviour of the cache will be different depending on things in that case.

I'm in favor of the first part of Mohammed's idea, where we build the direct download functionality into the image backend for rbd, try direct download if direct_location, else fall back on a fetch from glance. And only store the file on local disk. Adding logic to use rbd as the cache store would be complex, and Matt Booth pointed out it won't solve the use case described in this spec. So I think an rbd cache store would be a separate spec and effort.

Mohammed, not a fan of that proposal, and in any case it wouldn't address this use case. ImageCacheManager really needs to be taken out back and quietly put down, not extended.

I think what you're talking about is having an image cache appropriate to the image backend in use. i.e. If you're using ceph, your image cache should be in ceph; if you're using LVM it should be in LVM. That would allow us to efficiently use backend-specific thin copies. I'm in favour of this, I've proposed it in the past, and actually started implementing it, but unfortunately I don't think it will ever land. It's not a well-loved corner of Nova, and I believe the smart money these days is on improving boot from volume instead of maintaining a parallel implementation of cinder in nova. Apart from anything else, they support more backends than we ever will. They also have their own image cache.

The reason it wouldn't address this use case is that with a qcow2 backend we explicitly need an image cache which stores files on local disk, which an rbd image cache wouldn't achieve.
No need for us to use privsep and fork out a process, python-{rbd,rados} and co can help us get this done.
I also like to be Pythonic when possible but the primary purpose of this change is increasing download speed and I'm not sure we're going to get that level of performance from the Python bindings.

Executing an external binary is also likely to be vastly quicker. Python suffers severely from poor scheduling behaviour in operations like this. If you write a naive loop like:

while !finished:
  chunk = source.read()
  sink.write(chunk)

you fail to keep both your pipes busy simultaneously, and if you try to get clever by having separate reader and writer threads with a big buffer, you quickly hit limitations due to Python's inability to actually run the threads concurrently, or to service them quickly enough after an IO operation completes.

TL;DR Calling an external tool is much less code, and can easily be an order of magnitude faster when the speeds get high.

Indeed, running `rbd export` on a 2.2 GB image took 2.4s, while the same operation using Python bindings and the loop mentioned above took 7.2 seconds. I still like the "pythonic" way because it allows for code reuse, but potential performance benefits when using rbd export seem to be significant.
Yup, I pointed out librados in an earlier patch set, but the author wasn't familiar with using it for this, and the existing rbd image import call execs out.
Based on this thread, I think we should use privsep to execute 'rbd export' directly for performance reasons.
The only "alternative" to this proposed new behavior that I see is really just the "old" behavior of pushing image through API. Boot from volume is entirely different use case, not alternative.
This isn't needed, the behavior works for any image type that can be in Ceph.
I agree it can work for any image type.  It really just needs to be something other than rbd so that the image download code is invoked and doesn't try to run the VM's root disk from within Ceph.
Presumably this isn't required. I'd have assumed just the two below.
That's not needed, the image's "location" includes pool name.
Agreed, there is an implementation detail here we can hash out in the code review.

This is true, however the name of the option doesn't suggest it's "cinder-bound". Some environments reuse the same pool for Glance and Cinder and for those that don't, setting up access for one use to both pools is not an issue - Ceph supports that well.

I would rather we plumb this more formally somehow instead of using this extension point. We should keep it deprecated and move on to remove it after we get this functionality in-tree.

Does it make sense to always try to do this if the above things are configured? Seems like it would, maybe falling back to normal glance download if that fails or something? I'd rather do that than make operators opt-in to obviously sane behavior.

I might be wrong, I didn't fully audit the code, but I think the glance API code where the extension point is used today for downloads and where the rbd image backend exists for the libvirt driver might be quite a bit decoupled, unless it's the rbd image backend itself that is calling the download via some fetch_image() method or something. Note that also means you wouldn't get this optimization for non-libvirt drivers, but that's probably a much more minor concern.

Looks like the call path is:

libvirt driver _create_images_and_backing ->
  imagebackend.cache -> libvirt.utils.fetch_image ->
    images.fetch_to_raw -> images.fetch ->
      image.API.download -> glance (+download extension)

So I think the only place in there for the rbd imagebackend to side-step that is via the Rbd.cache method. Maybe that could work, or the Rbd imagebackend could provider a wrapper around the fetch_func or something?

+1 Dan. As I mentioned in a previous comment, I think we should just directly add the ability to direct download from ceph into the rbd imagebackend if the direct url is available and fall back to a fetch from glance if not. And go ahead and get rid of the extension point.

I'm ambivalent personally, but as this download is really an implementation detail of glance, not nova, some kind of extension would make sense. os-glance? Probably not worth it with just one extension, though.
Is this something we can test in the ceph job or only in unit tests?
See below, we would have to write an experimental queue job for the images_type=qcow2 thing since the ceph job runs with rbd everywhere (ephemeral and persistent).

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
What's KSM?

(Cause before I read through the patch, I thought it was keystonemiddleware :)

Also prefer if you tag this header with 'libvirt:'
Done
Need some more words here. Why are we doing this? The doc change indicates we're addressing performance? Freeze issues in Windows VMs? Is there a bug report and/or other links you could provide?

We got a support case at Mirantis and the solution was to disable KSM for qemu. A different approach was used (disabling via /etc/default/qemu-kvm: KSM_ENABLED=0) because nova does not have this functionality, but a per-vm / per-flavor approach is better, more flexible, hence this feature commit. Performance comes from "realtime" flag's description, as realtime flag disables KSM as well. It's also known that KSM increases RAM operation overhead, by design, so disabling it removes such overhead, increasing RAM performance.
Nice, thanks for this.

neutron/objects/qos/binding.py.message: Just wondering. Why not use 'get_objects' in here?

To improve the performance. With "get_objects" we are retrieving the DB object (the DB register plus the relationships) and then building the OVO instance. That takes more time than just retrieving one column from the model table, without the overload of the OVO layer.

Please describe in more details the meaning behind "port needs/doesn't need VMI/VPG"
Is it still valid point, since we have a sync thread
What is the point of this change? VMI stands for Virtual Machine Interface

This is not true.
A VPG may be connected to two nodes or it could be connected to one node. 

A node (host) can have more than one VPG. If a compute node has NIC card with multiple interfaces connected to multiple physical ports on the switch - These ports could be LAGed (I.e. multiple ports connected to the same switch). This LAG is represented as a VPG. These interfaces could be connected to different switches (this is called Multi-hommed LAG). This M-LAG is also represented by VPG.

You have listed the properties of VPG correctly though

To be precise, node here is a compute in Openstack, not fabric device. VPG aggregates physical interfaces in fabric's devices. As described below, ML2 plugin creates VPG per each compute and contains all physical interfaces (ports in fabric's devices) to which given compute via its data plane interfaces is connected, no matter that these physical interfaces belongs to one or more fabric devices.
I am not sure if I agree with this. Delete old port and create a new one? What if an attribute of a port is being updated? Port update is generally for that purpose.
I am not sure if I agree with this. What if a port update is just to update an attribute of a port? The actions should be similar to port create with some changes

Overall I agree you have right here. I think it have more sense for vRouter integration where we have to take care about port's attributes. In fabric case we don't care about port details. We only track number of ports in given network bound to particual host.If that number is greater that we need to create VMI (and attach to proper VPG) otherwise we need to delete VMI (if such VMI exists). To sum up for fabric I think it's okay to handle port update in that way.
